content:
What a great choice of book! "Sapiens" is a thought-provoking and engaging read. To further explore the history of humanity and its implications, here are some documentary and online course recommendations that might complement your reading:

**Documentaries:**

1. **"The Ascent of Man" (1973)**: A 13-part BBC series by Jacob Bronowski, exploring the evolution of humanity from a scientific and philosophical perspective.
2. **"The Story of Human Language" (1991)**: A 5-part PBS documentary series by John McWhorter, examining the development and diversity of human language.
3. **"The Human Spark" (2010)**: A 3-part PBS series by Alan Alda, investigating what makes us human, featuring interviews with experts in various fields.
4. **"The Ancient Apocalypse" (2012)**: A 2-part BBC documentary series exploring the collapse of ancient civilizations and the rise of new ones.
5. **"Rise of the Humans" (2019)**: A 3-part BBC series by Dr. Alice Roberts, delving into the evolution of Homo sapiens and our place in the natural world.

**Online Courses:**

1. **"Big History: The Big Bang, Life on Earth, and the Rise of Humanity"** (Coursera): A 12-week course by Dr. David Christian, exploring the history of the universe, life on Earth, and the emergence of humanity.
2. **"A Brief History of Humankind"** (edX): A 6-week course by Dr. Yuval Noah Harari himself, covering the same topics as his book.
3. **"The Origins of Humanity"** (FutureLearn): A 4-week course by Dr. Chris Stringer, examining the evolution of humans and our ancestors.
4. **"Human Evolution"** (MIT OpenCourseWare): A free online course covering the evolution of humans and our ancestors, taught by Dr. David Pilbeam.
5. **"The History of the World Since 1500 CE"** (edX): A 12-week course by Dr. Philip D. Curtin, exploring the global interactions and transformations that have shaped our modern world.

**Additional Resources:**

* **Crash Course** (YouTube): A popular educational channel with series on world history, science, and philosophy that might complement your learning.
* **Khan Academy** (YouTube): Khan Academy has an extensive collection of videos on world history, biology, and other relevant topics.
* **TED Talks** (YouTube): Search for talks by historians, anthropologists, and scientists like Yuval Noah Harari, Neil deGrasse Tyson, and Steven Pinker.

These resources should provide a rich supplement to your reading of "Sapiens" and offer a deeper understanding of the history of humanity and its implications for our world today. Enjoy!
